channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @ExpatInPL @WahlenPMattias @EydeDan @MarkHertling @jaketapper @ccn The radar will be a dozen meters or more above sea level, but yes, it’s not a tons of notice. Electronics work at nearly lightspeed, though… if a point-defense system is active and properly manned, it should only take seconds for target lock and gun/interceptor firing.

@markproxy Sounds like that’s the plan. Seems reasonable for disaster-type situations. Larger / more permanent installations might be able to use seafloor pipelines (like Chicago’s water cribs out in Lake Michigan), or use the energy for electrolysis & store hydrogen for powering ships.

@SEAsheltie @ChittiMarco It wasn’t a newly built rail alignment, however… freight had been running that area for years (which is why the speed warning signs were placed at optimal distance for freight train braking and not passenger traffic).
@talktidy @PhillipsPOBrien Right?! Think highjacked aircraft passengers’ attitudes / risk calculations before vs. after 9/11.
@vtchick67 @drStrohH @michaeldweiss https://t.co/rzOiqzjzB3
@nickreeves9876 @JulianRoepcke https://t.co/F1dv3dvvml
@Sanpaku1970 @JulianRoepcke At least they’ve finally learned to pack spare tires…
@Loobeeloo1980 @PhillipsPOBrien @Kembleford Russian rail gauge is wider than in most other regions, so perhaps their rail cars are wider as well?
@yemanouspeak @PhillipsPOBrien Good observation! Another benefit of using the ‘wagons’… there’s less concern of lose parts falling off and fouling the tracks.

@glogeex @Aviation_Intel Satellites are too far away to _reliably_ communicate with legacy ballistic missile submarines at (or below) periscope depth. The closer the transmitter, the easier it is to communicate through jamming or interference (e.g. interference caused by post-nuclear blast ionization).
@NatsLady @kemal_115 @oryxspioenkop https://t.co/Sr5JbtvH2O
@HansMus40081520 @oryxspioenkop I didn’t expect submarine warfare to play such a big role in this invasion!
@igorsushko I wasn’t meaning to argue; just sharing an alternative viewpoint. Thank you for all you have done with your translations and videos and the work you continue to do!

@DaveD1973 @MarkHertling That word seems to be reserved for mostly longer-range missiles? Honestly, the whole ‘hypersonic’ thing seems like a lot of hype. Objects that fast can easily be audibly triangulated; stand-off radar picket lines can communicate with distant defense systems at nearly lightspeed.
@politeabox @TrentTelenko … and even if the Russians didn’t need Ukraines oil and gas, they certainly didn’t want them as a competitor.
@LipkaPasha @TrentTelenko Size and shape appear to be distorted on the left and right edges of that photograph due to the lens used, so that ‘dune buggy’ probably is much narrower IRL.

@Ed_Fryer @PhillipsPOBrien They’ll probably start converting some roads to multi-gauge (i.e. 3 rails) as needed. Then, the existing equipment can be continued to be used. That’s what parts of Great Britain did when they changed gauges early on.
@borla_b @ericlevai For now, one can add “https://t.co/UmwOej9OLw” in front of most URLs to bypass news paywalls. Thanks to @12ftio

@Javier_F @BrianWhedon @Euan_MacDonald It sounds like the implication is that different sized ships are sometimes commanded by different ranks. US Navy example: - Enlisted NCO commands motor launch - LT commanded WWII PT boat - CDR commands fast-attack submarine - CAPT commands cruiser (generally)

@TheRobinCommon1 @BeauTFC Uncertainty can increase the psychological pressure on an enemy as well. Was it sabotage? Was it NATO frogmen? Was it divine retribution? Was it rouge Russian pilots? Did we deserve it somehow? If these types of questions distract even one Russian soldier, that’s a win.
